cluster_relations.rel_desc: Cinderella is treated as an example of a fairytale.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ExampleStatus: illustrative example of the genre

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Snow White is presented as an example of a fairytale.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ExampleStatus: illustrative example of the genre

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hansel and Gretel is described as one of the fairytale examples.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ExampleStatus: illustrative example of the genre

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Beauty and the Beast is treated as one of the fairytale examples.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ExampleStatus: illustrative example of the genre

args.canonical_rel_desc: Relates a general category or type to a specific instance or illustrative example of that category.
args.justification: In all four relations, the subject is the general category 'fairytales' and the object is a specific tale (Cinderella, Snow White, Hansel and Gretel, Beauty and the Beast) used as an example. This is a standard type–instance (class–individual) pattern and can be consistently modeled with the canonical predicate 'has_instance'.

Each relation encodes that a specific story is an example/instance of the broader category 'fairytales', which is a classic type–instance (class–individual) membership relation. Grouping them under a shared relation class 'type_instance_relation' captures this family of semantics.

Type–instance (class–individual) links are fundamentally about classificatory identity and membership (identifying a particular as belonging to a given type). Among the broad semantic groups, 'IDENTITY' best covers this category–instance relationship.

Each relation encodes that a specific story is an example/instance of the broader category 'fairytales', which is a classic type–instance (class–individual) membership relation. Grouping them under a shared relation class 'type_instance_relation' captures this family of semantics.
